Simulator sickness in patients with neck pain and vestibular pathology during virtual reality tasks
Download PDF
Download PDF
  • Original Article
  • Published: 22 September 2017

Simulator sickness in patients with neck pain and vestibular pathology during virtual reality tasks

  • Ryan Tyrrell  ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0003-0011-20721,
  • Hilla Sarig-Bahat1,2,
  • Katrina Williams1,
  • Grace Williams1 &
  • Julia Treleaven1 

Virtual Reality volume 22, pages211–219(2018)Cite this article

  • 1178 Accesses

  • 6 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

  • Metrics details

Abstract

Immersion in virtual environments can cause simulator sickness (SS). Further, head and neck movement in interactive virtual reality (VR) assessment and training stimulates the vestibular and cervical afferent systems that can cause dizziness in subjects with neck pain and vestibular pathology. This cross-sectional, observational, study investigated SS and factors that may influence this between 20 neck pain, 14 vestibular pathology and 20 asymptomatic control subjects. Pre-VR questionnaires included a visual symptom scale and dizziness intensity. SS measures included the simulator sickness visual analogue scale and the simulator sickness questionnaire. Significantly greater incidence of any SS and higher values were found in the vestibular and neck pain groups compared to the control group in selected SS measures. No significant differences were found when comparing SS measures between the vestibular and neck pain groups. Significant mild-to-moderate correlations for the entire population were found between both SS measures to pre-VR visual symptoms and dizziness intensity. SS levels in neck pain and vestibular populations are comparable and higher than asymptomatic individuals. Dizziness and visual disturbances may be associated with an increase in severity of SS in these clinical populations.

Introduction

Chronic neck pain is an increasingly common problem (Hoy et al. 2010). It results in both physical impairments and functional limitations including aberrant cervical movement patterns (Sjøogaard et al. 2000; Tsang et al. 2013). The importance of cervical kinematic assessment and training, which comprises velocity, accuracy and range of neck movement has been gaining attention (Bahat et al. 2010; Sarig Bahat et al. 2009, 2014, 2015a, b).

A promising new and novel modality in assessment and delivery of this cervical kinematic training is utilising virtual reality (VR) technology via a neck VR system specifically designed for this purpose (Bahat et al. 2010; Sarig-Bahat et al. 2009, 2015b, 2016). The user in the neck VR system wears a head mounted display and controls a virtual airplane with their head motion to accurately follow or reach selected targets placed at different distances and directions. Various tasks are designed to assess and train dynamic control of neck motion such as velocity, accuracy and range of neck motion. Immersion in VR tasks in general is claimed to improve motivation, engagement and compliance over conventional modalities (Bryanton et al. 2006).

Further, head and neck movement during the VR interaction stimulates the vestibular, visual and neck afferent systems, which combined with vision provide important information for sensorimotor control of head and eye movement and postural stability. Such stimulation could also influence dizziness and visual disturbances, which are common complaints in neck pain (Treleaven 2011; Treleaven and Takasaki 2014). Individuals with vestibular pathology share similarities to those with neck pain, with reports of dizziness and visual disturbances also common (Treleaven 2011; Treleaven et al. 2008), as well as possible increased neck stiffness, in response to attempting to avoid episodes of dizziness (Wilhelmsen and Kvale 2014; Winteler et al. 2009). Subsequently, this group of patients may also benefit from cervical kinematic assessment and training.

Nevertheless, despite the potential benefits of VR kinematic training in these patient populations, simulator sickness (SS) is a common side effect as reported in VR studies (Chu et al. 2013; Treleaven et al. 2015a). To consider such application for future management, it is essential to screen the level and prevalence of such side effects in the designated patient population. The majority of research has been conducted in asymptomatic individuals and based upon concepts of motion sickness, but it is likely a separate malady (Brooks et al. 2010; Kennedy et al. 1993; Ohyama et al. 2007). A number of theories regarding the cause and influencing factors of SS have been developed. The three most widely accepted are: the sensory conflict, postural instability and eye movement theories (Brooks et al. 2010; Warwick-Evans et al. 1998). The four primary symptoms of SS are pallor, cold sweating, nausea and vomiting (Sharples et al. 2008). SS can also alter ability to concentrate and adjust to feedback (Hettinger et al. 1990; Kawano et al. 2012).

In a recent study using VR to assess cervical kinematics, SS incidence in asymptomatic individuals was 28%, and related to VR emersion time as well as motion sickness susceptibility as a child (Treleaven et al. 2015a). It is possible that individuals with neck pain or vestibular pathology may have an increased risk of SS when using the neck VR system due to potential deficits in the neck or vestibular sensory systems that may result in greater sensory conflict. Further, individual’s already experiencing dizziness or visual disturbances (thought to be due to sensory conflict) may have further provocation or exacerbation of these symptoms when using VR. In order to progress with this research it will be important to identify SS incidence and potential factors that may influence this in populations with neck pain and vestibular pathology. This study aims to examine SS and side effects of VR in individuals with neck pain and individuals with vestibular pathology compared with asymptomatic controls using the neck VR system. In addition, this study aimed to explore the relationship between SS and other factors that may influence it.

Method

Design overview

This was a cross-sectional, observational study with three populations sought: subjects with neck pain, subjects with vestibular pathology and asymptomatic control subjects. Participants were primarily matched according to age, with gender also a consideration. Each subject completed one supervised session for approximately 30 min. Participants were required to complete a number of questionnaires prior to participating in the study.

Setting and participants

Recruitment was performed through physical advertisements within the local community and directly to select non-profit and vestibular pathology support organisations via social media from April to August 2015. The study itself was conducted in the Neck Pain and Whiplash Research Unit at [concealed for blind reviewing].

Asymptomatic control subjects were excluded if they had any existing vestibular pathology, neck disability index (NDI) score greater than 10%, history of traumatic head/brain injury, systemic disease, cervical fracture or dislocation, neurological/cardiovascular/respiratory disorders affecting physical performance, inability to provide informed consent, or were pregnant.

Inclusion criteria for subjects with neck pain included a NDI score greater than 10% and persistent neck pain for more than 3 months. Exclusion criteria were as listed above.

Inclusion criteria for subjects with vestibular pathology included a diagnosis of acoustic neuroma (a benign tumour on the vestibular nerve) or Meniere’s disease (a disorder of the inner ear thought to be due to fluid buildup). These conditions were chosen as both cause discreet unilateral vestibular pathology and can be easily diagnosed by a medical doctor. A clinical examination of balance, ocular control, gaze stability and visual vertical prior to admission was also performed to ensure each subject had some ongoing vestibular impairment. Exclusion criteria included miscellaneous or undiagnosed vestibular disorders, an NDI score greater than 10%, and those other excluded health conditions listed for the control subjects.

Ethics

This study obtained ethical approval in accordance with the ethical review guidelines and processes of [concealed for blind reviewing]. All subjects gave their express written informed consent prior to participating in the study.

Apparatus and virtual stimuli

A customised neck VR system with off-the-shelf hardware (Oculus Rift™ Development Kit 2 by Oculus VR, California) and customised software developed using Unity-pro software (version 3.5 by Unity Technologies, San Francisco) was used to provide the VR stimulus. The identical software was used in a previous study by Sarig Bahat et al. (2015a, b) to immerse subjects into an interactive virtual environment. The Oculus Rift head mounted display provided three-dimensional motion real-time tracking of the head and neck to enable interaction during the three VR tasks. The three tasks were designed to assess or train neck velocity, accuracy and range of motion (ROM) in that order as these had incremental increases in immersion time which could have influenced SS. Each task aimed to provoke particular neck movements in response to visual stimuli, and the objectives of each task have been previously described in detail by Sarig Bahat et al. (2015a, b). During VR immersion, the subject controls a virtual pilot in an aeroplane using neck movements to interact with targets appearing in four directions—up, down, right and left. This might include moving the head and neck in a direction to reach a distant target (ROM task), stabilising the head and then moving the head and neck quickly to reach a target (velocity task) and moving the head and neck accurately to follow precisely a moving target (accuracy task).

Pre-study questionnaires

Neck disability index (NDI) is a self-report questionnaire used to determine how neck pain affects a patient’s daily life. It incorporates ten items scored on a 0–5 scale and calculated as a percentage to quantify self-perceived disability associated with NP (Vernon and Mior 1991).

Visual symptoms scale (VSS) was used to determine whether a subject’s condition (neck pain or vestibular pathology) had affected or disturbed their vision. The scale rated the frequency and severity of four factors. The product of a maximal score of 3 for frequency and 4 for severity for each of the items was obtained, and then, the sum of these four items was used to derive a maximal score of 48. The items included visual fatigue, sensitivity to light, needing to concentrate to focus and eye strain, with a higher score indicating a greater level of severity and frequency (Treleaven and Takasaki 2014).

The dizziness handicap inventory (DHI) is a 25-item questionnaire designed to evaluate self-perceived functional, physical and emotional aspects associated with dizziness. DHI is scored from 0–100, with a higher score indicating a greater level of handicap (Jacobson and Newman 1990).

Dizziness visual analogue scale (dizziness VAS) was used to record the intensity of dizziness on a scale from 0 to 10, with 0 representing nil symptoms and 10 representing the worst symptoms imaginable. Participants marked their level of symptoms on a 100-mm line prior to immersion into the first VR module (pre-dizziness VAS) and then immediately after the testing (post-dizziness VAS).

Simulator sickness measures

Two measures of simulator sickness were used in this study. These included measures of the overall intensity of SS as well as the number and severity of symptoms associated with SS.

Simulator sickness visual analogue scale (SS-VAS) was used to record the intensity of SS. Participants marked their level of symptoms with a single line or cross at the point on a 100-mm line, with 0 representing nil symptoms and 10 representing the worst symptoms imaginable immediately following immersion into each of the three VR tasks as described above in the virtual stimuli (velocity, accuracy and ROM). These were then combined to give an accumulative score, SS-VAS out of 300 mm. The SS-VAS measure has been used in a previous VR study and established a number of clinically valuable predictors from its use (Treleaven et al. 2015a).

The simulator sickness questionnaire (SSQ) is considered the current gold standard in measuring SS in research (Jinjakam and Hamamoto 2012; Kennedy et al. 1993). The scores are divided up into three subsections of seven symptoms each, of which some overlap: disorientation, nausea and oculomotor. The symptoms include general discomfort, fatigue, headache, eyestrain, difficulty focusing, increase salivation, sweating, nausea, difficulty concentrating, fullness of head, blurred vision, dizzy (eyes open), dizzy (eyes closed), vertigo, stomach awareness and burping. A weighted score procedure was used to obtain a global index, which reflects the total discomfort level, as well as scores along the three subsections. The three subsections were calculated by summing the scores associated with each subscale/4 for each item, and multiplying by an appropriate weighting factor (9.54 for SSQ-Nausea, 7.58 for SSQ-Oculomotor, and 13.92 for SSQ-Disorientation) as per previous research (Kennedy et al. 1993). The SSQ-Total score/300 was equal to the sum of the three subscales, multiplied by 3.7. This weighted SSQ procedure is commonly used in VR studies (Jumisko-Pyykkö et al. 2010; Sparto et al. 2004), with higher scores indicating a greater level of SS symptoms experienced (Kennedy et al. 1993). It has also been shown that a score of greater than 20 on the total weighted score represents that subjects are experiencing sufficient discomfort in simulated environments (Webb et al. 2009).

Other measures

ROM module time: For the purposes of this study, the time taken (seconds) to complete the ROM module was recorded as this had previously been shown to relate to SS in asymptomatic individuals (Treleaven et al. 2015a). Variations in completion of this task can occur depending on the success rate of reaching the targets, which are automatically increased in distance once a target has been successfully reached. Three attempts are given at each distance.

The motion sickness susceptibility questionnaire short form (MSSQ Short) was used to determine differences in a subject’s motion sickness susceptibility caused by a range of stimuli. Participants rated each stimulus from 0 to 3 from their childhood experience before the age of 12 (MSSQ Child). A maximum score of 27 is possible, with a higher score indicating higher levels of MS susceptibility (Golding 2006).

Procedure

All participants completed the consent form, demographics, pre-VR questionnaires relating to neck pain, visual disturbances and dizziness—NDI, VSS, DHI and pre-dizziness VAS.

Following the completion of these questionnaires, subjects completed each of the three VR tasks. Participants were secured to the chair via a seat belt harness to minimise unwanted trunk movement during the VR interactivity, as motion tracking was recorded via the head mounted display. The assessor then explained each of the three tasks, and the participant performed an introductory practice to familiarise the subject with the virtual environment. Ordering of the tasks was kept consistent for each participant, with velocity first, followed by accuracy and ROM last, as ROM has previously been shown to be most associated with SS (Treleaven et al. 2015). SS-VAS was recorded after each task along with whether the participant required an extended rest break between tasks greater than the standard 60 s. Immediately upon the conclusion of the ROM task, participants completed the post-dizziness VAS, motion sickness questionnaire (MSSQ Child) and SSQ, to avoid potential heightened self-awareness of symptoms of SS prior to VR immersion. At 24-h post-study, all participants were contacted to investigate whether they were experiencing ongoing or delayed symptoms of SS with their responses recorded.

Statistical analysis

Data were explored for outliers as well as normality. Differences between groups for gender using Fisher’s exact test were performed and nonparametric statistics used in any cases of non-normalised data. Age was normally distributed, and a one-way ANOVA was used to compare age between the groups. Analysis for group difference between each of the SS measures was performed using Mann–Whitney U tests. Multiple comparison testing (between each of the groups) was used post hoc if any differences were detected between the three groups.

Nonparametric statistics using bivariate correlation analysis between the SS questionnaires (SSQ-Total, SSQ-Nausea, SSQ-Oculomotor, SSQ-Disorientation, SS-VAS), motion sickness as a child (MSSQ Child), time of emersion on the range of motion task (ROM Time), and dizziness and visual symptoms (pre-dizziness VAS, post–pre-dizziness VAS, DHI and VSS) were calculated using a two-tailed Spearman’s rank calculation. Interpretation of the strength of correlations between variables was 0 = no association, 0.30 = mild association, 0.50 = moderate association and 0.70 = strong association, with the direction being either positive or negative (Chiu et al. 2005). Significance was determined at p < 0.05. SPSS version 22 software was used for analyses.

Results

Fifty-four participants (20 control, 20 neck pain and 14 vestibular pathology participants) were recruited, and all completed the study. Group characteristics are shown in Table 1. There were no statistically significant between group differences for age or gender.

Simulator sickness measures for both the SSQ and SS-VAS for each of the three groups are depicted in Table 2. For the SSQ which included three subsection scores: SSQ-Nausea, SSQ-Oculomotor and SSQ-Disorientation, and the SSQ-Total, significantly higher values (p < 0.05) were found in the vestibular group compared to the control group in most measures. A significant difference was also found when comparing the neck pain group to the control group for SSQ-Oculomotor (p = 0.008). No significant differences were found when comparing the neck pain group to the vestibular pathology group on any SSQ measure.

When using the SS-VAS intensity measure which included the combined SS intensity score of the three VR tasks, significant differences (p < 0.05) were found when comparing the neck pain group to the control group, but there were no significant differences between the vestibular pathology and the control group.

The percentages of subjects in each group with nil (SSQ-Total >0), mild (SSQ-Total >20) and moderate (SSQ-Total >50) SS symptoms and nil, mild and moderate SS-VAS intensity are depicted in Table 3a, b. There were significant differences between groups in proportion of subjects for both nil SSQ and SS-VAS, but not for any of the mild or severe levels of SS. Delayed motion sickness was reported to be mild and occurred in 15% of both the control and neck pain groups and in 29% of the vestibular pathology group.

Correlations between the various measures were calculated for the whole study population (Table 4), in the vestibular pathology group (Table 5) and in the neck pain group (Table 6). Significant mild-to-moderate correlations were found between SSQ-Total to dizziness intensity (dizziness VAS) (r = 0.48) and visual symptoms (VSS) (r = 0.5), as well as SS-VAS to immersion time (ROM time) (r = 0.33), dizziness intensity (dizziness VAS) (r = 0.32) and visual symptoms (VSS) (r = 0.42) in the whole study population. In the neck pain group, significant mild-to-moderate correlations between SSQ-Total to motion sickness as a child (MSSQ Child) (r = 0.56) and dizziness intensity (dizziness VAS) (r = 0.54) were seen. In the vestibular pathology group, a significant moderate correlation between SSQ-Total and visual symptoms (VSS) (r = 0.69) was seen.

Discussion

The results of this study demonstrated increased incidence and magnitude and simulator sickness measures in both the neck pain and vestibular pathology groups compared with the asymptomatic controls depending on the measure used. Pre-immersion levels of dizziness and/or visual disturbances seem to be most consistently related to measures of SS. The results point to some areas for future research and factors that might help predict and measure SS in these groups to allow the neck VR system to be used safely and effectively in these populations.

Incidence and severity of simulator sickness

The results of this study demonstrated significantly increased incidence and magnitude of SS in both the neck pain and vestibular pathology groups compared with the asymptomatic controls using both measures of SS which included a standardised questionnaire the SSQ as well intensity of SS as measured by the SS-VAS (Tables 2, 3).

The average SSQ-Total scores in the neck pain (43.2), vestibular pathology (49.2) and control (21.8) groups are consistent with a previous study in asymptomatic individuals (Treleaven et al. 2015b), and although the scores for both the neck pain and vestibular pathology groups are more than double than those of controls, they are within a comparable range of expected mean SSQ results reported in previous studies using virtual environments with asymptomatic individuals (Braithwaite and Braithwaite 1990 Kennedy et al. 1993; Merhi et al. 2007; Regan and Price 1994).

Further, in spite of the reported level of side effects, no participant had to withdraw from the study due to SS or any other reason; however, approximately 19% of total participants reported prolonged or latent symptoms 24 h post-study although this was reported by the subjects to be mild. The vestibular pathology group experienced the largest proportion (29%) with approximately twice the reported cases compared to the other groups (15%). This would imply that the levels of simulator sickness experienced by these groups are comparable to other studies and thus acceptable and would not necessarily suggest that the neck VR system should not be used in these populations. However, it is possible that subjects with vestibular pathology may be more susceptible to prolonged exacerbation due to existing higher levels of dizziness, and thus, this should be monitored closely within the 24 h post-immersion.

The increased and comparable results for SSQ for both the neck pain and vestibular pathology groups in comparison with the control group suggest that either there is a difference between the symptomatic (neck pain and vestibular pathology) and asymptomatic subjects or perhaps that the neck pain and vestibular pathology groups were already experiencing some of the symptoms listed on the SSQ prior to VR emersion, such as blurred vision or dizziness. This may explain some of the difference in results between simulator sickness measures by the SS symptoms SSQ and as measured by SS intensity SS-VAS.

In this study, to gain a SS-VAS following each of the three VR tasks, participants were consistently and deliberately asked whether they were ‘feeling well’ rather than if they were ‘feeling sick’. Only if the participant responded with ‘not feeling well’ would a SS-VAS be obtained. This process was implemented to avoid anticipatory SS (Young et al. 2007).

Similarly to the Treleaven et al. (2015a, b) study, some participants who did not state a SS-VAS during immersion reported symptoms on the SSQ. Young et al. (2007) describe this inconsistency as ‘demand characteristics’ due to exposure to a set of descriptive symptoms as outlined in the SSQ. Only one previous study has used SS-VAS as a potential predictor of SS (Treleaven et al. 2015a). It was described as an alternative measure to avoid the ‘demand characteristics’ phenomenon in addition to providing separate monitoring of symptoms immediately following multiple VR modules. Using the SS-VAS would also avoid questions specifically regarding visual and dizziness complaints that these participants might already be experiencing.

Thus, in populations who may already be experiencing some symptoms that are common in VR use, the SSQ may not be the most suitable to measure the level of SS. Instead, change in level of SS intensity (SS-VAS) may be the most suitable measure to indicate a change in symptoms specifically related to the task at hand.

Factors influencing simulator sickness

Interestingly pre-immersion levels of both dizziness and visual disturbances were positively correlated with measures of SS (r .37–.52), suggesting that these factors may have an influence on the severity of SS in neck pain and vestibular pathology populations. This finding may be due to the existing potential deficits in the cervical or vestibular sensory systems in such populations resulting in greater sensory conflict and thus greater SS when compared to asymptomatic individuals or may be due to the use of these factors as items in the questionnaires. Interestingly, there was no relationship between change of dizziness pre-to-post-VR emersion and measures of SS. Furthermore, on average dizziness levels were unchanged or improved rather than worsened in the neck pain and vestibular pathology group post-emersion (Table 1). This has implications for potential use of the system to be used to improve symptoms of dizziness, but more research is required.

Both time of emersion in the VR ROM module (ROM Time) and motion sickness susceptibility as a child (MSSQ Child) were found to have a mild positive correlation with SS (r > .29), similar to that found in the previous study by Treleaven et al. (2015a) with asymptomatic individuals. These results support existing literature identifying the association between VR emersion time and child motion sickness susceptibility and increased SS susceptibility (Jerome et al. 2005; Moss and Muth 2011). Future research should consider VR emersion time, and more research will be required to investigate what is the ideal whilst still effective VR duration for the purposes of assessment and training, which will induce minimal side effects. Furthermore, research is needed to investigate the specificity and reliability of using the MSSQ in neck pain and vestibular pathology populations with larger sample sizes. Due to the enhanced development of VR applications in the rehabilitation field, such knowledge about factors that influence SS susceptibility could assist in identifying those who may develop SS during exposure to VR and possible ways of reducing the severity of symptoms. This is very important considering the rapid development of VR and its utilisation as a specialised modality for cervical kinematic assessment and training in neck pain and vestibular pathology populations.

Limitations

The sample size used in this study was comparably small with a total of 54 participants. Recruitment of subjects for the VP group was particularly difficult due to the strict inclusion and exclusion criteria. Future research should include a larger sample sizes if possible. In this study, we deliberately excluded VP subjects who also experienced neck pain. However, it will be of interest to look at this group in the future.

Another limitation was the lack of measures used to record anxiety and fear of movement. It is common for neck pain and vestibular pathology populations to experience an onset or exacerbation of symptoms such as dizziness with head and neck movements. Subsequently, it is possible that anxiety may heighten effects of sickness and fear of movement may dull the effects, due to avoidance of movement (Bouchard et al. 2009; Ling et al. 2011; Paillard et al. 2013). The relationship between fear of movement and ROM has previously been examined and was found to have a moderate correlation (Sarig Bahat et al. 2014). Further research is needed to investigate the aforementioned effects, specifically within neck pain and vestibular pathology populations.

Further, it is possible that subjects with neck pain or vestibular pathology may have experienced some of these symptoms purely by performing the neck and head movements, regardless of the virtual environment. Future research could explore this; however, it is more important to understand the effects whilst in the VR, as this method is vital for clinical assessment of all of the features of cervical kinematics (Sarig Bahat et al. 2014).

Conclusion

The results of this study support the hypothesis that patients with neck pain and vestibular pathology similarly have an increased rating of SS when using a VR device, in comparison with asymptomatic individuals, although this level would seem to be acceptable such that VR use would not be contraindicated in these groups. The results also suggest that pre-immersion levels of dizziness and visual disturbances are associated with an increase in incidence and severity of SS in neck pain and vestibular pathology populations or could be related to the measures, and thus, consideration to the most appropriate measure to assess SS will be important in these populations. Immersion time should also be limited as much as possible and considered with future protocol development.

Furthermore, this study indicates validity in conducting further trials investigating cervical VR kinematic training in those with neck pain and vestibular pathology as although SS was increased, it was relatively mild and short lasting and thus likely acceptable to the users. More investigation into subjects with vestibular pathology experiencing virtual environments is needed to assist in better predicting potential influencing factors of SS susceptibility in this population as well as exploring the positive beneficial effects.
